text:
On testnet i try to recover node from identities dump  with

`./start.sh -s "<https://sv.sv-2.test.global.canton.network.digitalasset.com>" -p meria-validator-001 -o "" -m 3 -i '/mnt/block-volume/canton/canton/' -P meria-validator-002`

but i always got this error

 `INTERNAL: Node has ID PAR::meria-validator-001::1220ead4437f... instead of expected ID PAR::meria-validator-002::122012490402....` 

is it a must to update the identities name in the json file ? Have any easy procedure to find the <party_hint>::<fingerprint_of_public_key> ?

text:
Hi,
We would like to run Canton validator node. For this, we would need to find sponsor (i.e. some organization with SV).
I have several questions related to sponsors:
- Are there any differences between sponsors?
- Are there any requirements imposed on us by the sponsor?
- Any suggestions on how to find sponsors?
If there are answers in docs to some or all of my questions, you can just point them to me.

Hello all, requesting whitelist of IP `18.116.55.64` on DevNet (sponsor Digital Asset)
cc. <@U03T53E1N>, <@U04KJF6UTNU>

on DevNet (sponsor Digital Asset)
cc.

text: Hello all, we recently asked to whitelist 3 IPs for our DevNet validator. This will run on a Kubernetes cluster spread across 3 availability zones in order to be fault tolerant. It is probably an overkill for a DevNet node, however it doesn't seem unreasonable for a production one. We got push-back when it came to whitelisting these 3 IPs, which means we are doing something unusual. Can you please explain what is the common practice, and if it is OK to rely on 3 IPs for redundancy in a production setting? Thanks a lot!

elements.text: Hello all, we recently asked to whitelist 3 IPs for our DevNet validator. This will run on a Kubernetes cluster spread across 3 availability zones in order to be fault tolerant. It is probably an overkill for a DevNet node, however it doesn't seem unreasonable for a production one. We got push-back when it came to whitelisting these 3 IPs, which means we are doing something unusual. Can you please explain what is the common practice, and if it is OK to rely on 3 IPs for redundancy in a production setting? Thanks a lot!

text: <@UCCBNQECD> Private K8S cluster. Whatever the number of nodes or number of AZ/zones, it would go out using a single IP address

elements.text: Private K8S cluster. Whatever the number of nodes or number of AZ/zones, it would go out using a single IP address

text: (with public K8S cluster, each node does Egress with its own IP). Private does route trafic on nodes to NAT Gateway, which IP is the only one visible from outside

elements.text: (with public K8S cluster, each node does Egress with its own IP). Private does route trafic on nodes to NAT Gateway, which IP is the only one visible from outside

text: This message was deleted.
OK we have 1 NAT gateway in each availability zone. It seems to mean that we need 3 IPs as a result.
